item.title: US Farm Sentiment at 4-Year High as Trump Seeks Trade Deals
item.description: American farmer sentiment jumped to a four-year high, with growers betting on rising crop exports as the Trump administration pushes for more trade deals from Vietnam to Italy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Hirtzer, Erin Ailworth, Skylar Woodhouse

item.title: South Korea Elects Lee President, Capping Six Months of Chaos
item.description: South Korea’s opposition candidate Lee Jae-myung vowed to improve people’s livelihoods as his main rival acknowledged defeat in a presidential election that was largely a verdict on ousted leader Yoon Suk Yeol’s botched attempt to revive martial law after decades of democratic rule.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, presidential candidate for the Democratic Party, left, and his wife Kim Hye-gyeong at the party's election night event in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. With almost 95% of the ballots counted, Lee, a left-leaning former labor activist, had won 48.8% of the vote while the ruling People Power Party’s candidate Kim Moon-soo had 42.0%, according the National Election Commission, a narrower margin than indicated by an earlier exit poll.

item.title: Bank of Canada Likely to Hold as Uncertainty Mounts: Decision Guide
item.description: The Bank of Canada is likely to hold interest rates steady as officials wait for clearer signals on how US President Donald Trump’s trade war will end up striking the economy.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Tiff Macklem, governor of the Bank of Canada, during a news conference in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The Bank of Canada is warning that the ongoing tariff dispute has "rattled markets" and increases the risk of "disorderly" sell-offs that would test the country's financial system.

item.title: Trump Signs Order Hiking Steel, Aluminum Tariffs to 50%
item.description: President Donald Trump signed a directive on Tuesday raising steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% from 25% starting on June 4, following through on a pledge to boost import taxes to help domestic manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: A crane moves a roll of coiled steel at a steel plant in Hamilton, Ontario. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

item.title: Traders Load Up on Hedges Against Dramatic Fed Rate Cut Shifts
item.description: Traders are ramping up bets that hedge against dramatic shifts in the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate path as questions on the economic impact of Trump’s administration evolving policies persist.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

item.title: Bureau of Labor Statistics to Correct ‘Minor Errors’ in April’s US Jobs Data
item.description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics said it will correct “minor errors” in April jobs data on Friday with the release of figures for May, adding the changes won’t affect key measures such as the unemployment rate.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Boesler

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Risk appetites vanished on Wall Street after the biggest burst of buying in years, with stocks falling even after subdued inflation data extended a bounce in Treasuries. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Rushes to Save US Steel Tariff Deal Before Levies Double
item.description: The UK is pushing the US to remove tariffs on British steel exports in line with a deal struck last month, ahead of a planned blanket doubling of levies.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: Molten steel at a plant in Sheffield, UK. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

item.title: Elon Musk Blasts Trump Tax Bill as Budget-Busting ‘Abomination’
item.description: Donald Trump ally Elon Musk lambasted the president’s signature tax bill as a budget-busting “abomination” as Republican fiscal hawks stepped up criticism of the massive fiscal package.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: Senator Rand Paul

item.title: Fed’s Cook Underscores Importance of Price Stability
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook said she sees tariffs as potentially stoking inflation and weakening employment, yet underscored the importance of price stability when considering future interest-rate adjustments.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Lisa Cook, governor of the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a Fed Listens event in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, March 22, 2024. A trio of central bank decisions this week sent a clear message to markets that officials are preparing to loosen monetary policy, reigniting investor appetite for risk. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: US Sent Letters to Trade Partners Ahead of Tariff Deadline
item.description: The Office of the US Trade Representative has sent letters to trading partners to remind them of an upcoming deadline in tariff negotiations, according to the White House, an effort by the Trump administration to push forward talks.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: The Office of the US Trade Representative seal before a signing ceremony with Katherine Tai, US trade representative, and Koji Tomita, Japan's ambassador to the US, for an agreement to increase the beef safeguard trigger level under the US-Japan Trade Agreement in Washington, D.C., US, on Thursday, June 2, 2022. The new safeguard mechanism will allow US exporters to meet Japan's growing demand for beef and reduce the probability that Japan will impose higher tariffs in the future, according to the Office of the US Trade Representative. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Central Bank Sees ‘Amazing’ Chance to Lower CPI Goal
item.description: South Africa’s current low level of inflation is an unmissable chance to reduce the country’s inflation target and lock in the benefits of tame price pressures and cheaper borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba

item.title: SNB’s Tschudin Says Monthly Inflation Number Just One Data Point
item.description: The Swiss National Bank won’t be distracted by monthly inflation numbers, according to a senior official.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Shoppers cross tram tracks in Zurich, Switzerland, on Sunday, Sept. 25, 2022. Inflation in Switzerland has more than doubled since the start of the year and the State Secretariat for Economic Affairs expects it to come in at a three-decade-high of 3% for 2022. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed’s Bostic Wants More Progress on Inflation, in No Rush to Cut
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said he’s in no rush to move interest rates, adding he wants to see “a lot” more progress on inflation despite recent encouraging price data.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic.

item.title: NY Fed Says Net Income Could Be Negative Through Most of 2025
item.description: Total net income from the Federal Reserve’s System Open Market Account could remain negative on an annual basis in 2025 before returning to positive levels as early as next year, according to new projections from the New York Fed.
item.dc:creator: Alex Harris

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, Jan. 12, 2025. The US Treasury market is leading a reset higher in borrowing costs, with potentially wide-ranging consequences. Photographer: Samuel Corum/Bloomberg

item.title: Carney’s Budget Delay Adds to Economic Uncertainty in Canada, Analysts Say
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s decision to delay Canada’s budget until later this year increases economic uncertainty but isn’t likely to spark worries among investors, say a majority of economists in a Bloomberg survey.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg, Dana Morgan

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney.

item.title: France Says Positive Outcome Possible in Cognac Probe Talks With China
item.description: France’s trade minister said he believes Beijing and Paris can resolve a spat over duties on Cognac that is hammering French producers and complicating broader discussions on global commerce.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Bottles of French cognac displayed at an independent winegrowers fair in Paris, France, on Friday, March 21, 2025. A sector-by-sector tariff approach by US President Donald Trump risks creating divisions among European Union member states, Micheal Martin, Ireland's prime minister, said.

item.title: US Job Openings Unexpectedly Rose in April and Hiring Picked Up
item.description: US job openings unexpectedly rose in April in a fairly broad advance and hiring picked up, indicating demand for workers remains healthy despite heightened economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Applicants at a job and resource fair in Fletcher, North Carolina.

item.title: Dutch Government Crisis Risks Slowing EU Decisions, ING CEO Says
item.description: The collapse of the Dutch government risks slowing decisions related to Europe’s planned investment spree, said ING Groep NV Chief Executive Officer Steven van Rijswijk.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jacob, Steven Arons

media:content.media:description: Steven van Rijswijk

item.title: BOE Officials Defend Diverging Views With Inflation Path Unclear
item.description: Bank of England rate-setters defended their wide range of views on the direction of monetary policy as they laid out to lawmakers starkly different opinions on the outlook for inflation.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: The Bank of England. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Team Signals It Wants to Keep Control of Fannie, Freddie to Boost Budget
item.description: Signs are emerging that the Trump administration may be less willing to give up control of mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac than investors have bargained for, as policymakers scrounge for ways to close US budget gaps.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: A residential neighborhood in San Marcos, Texas.

item.title: China Criticizes EU’s Planned Curb on Medical Device Procurement
item.description: Beijing criticized as protectionist the European Union’s plan to curb Chinese medical device manufacturers’ access to public procurement contracts and vowed to take action to protect the country’s interests.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: A worker checks parts at a factory which produces medical endoscope lenses in Hangzhou, in China's eastern Zhejiang province on October 31, 2024. China's manufacturing output expanded this month for the first time since April, official data showed on October 31, rare good news for leaders struggling to boost activity in the world's second-largest economy. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT (Photo by STR/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: STR/AFP

item.title: South Africa’s High Court Rejects Bid to Halt Fuel Levy Increase
item.description: South Africa’s High Court dismissed a lawsuit filed by the opposition Economic Freedom Fighters party that sought to stop the government from raising fuel levies.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: A worker handles a diesel pump at a Texaco Inc. gas station in Pretoria, South Africa, on Wednesday, Nov. 3, 2021. South Africa's gasoline prices rose to a record on Wednesday, adding to inflationary pressures in an economy that imports almost all of its fuel.

item.title: Bailey Says BOE Can Cut Faster If Inflation Risks Undershoot
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said it would need to ditch its cautious approach to cutting interest rates and act more aggressively if officials saw a threat of undershooting their 2% inflation target.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey Photographer: Patrick Bolger/Bloomberg

item.title: Saudi Arabia's Hurdles at Home Are Reshaping the Mideast Financial Order
item.description: Bankers and business leaders are shifting more attention toward the kingdom’s neighbors in the Gulf as it grapples with lower oil prices and weakening finances.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Martin, Dinesh Nair, Adveith Nair

media:content.media:description: Saudi Arabia needs to bring in foreign capital to continue spending.

item.title: South Africa Avoids Contraction as Growth Outlook Remains Dim
item.description: South Africa’s economy narrowly escaped an expected contraction in the first three months of the year as farming surged, but the outlook remains challenging amid weak investment.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: Workers picking grapefruit on an orchard outside Hoedspruit, South Africa.

item.title: Rising Security Risks Push Denmark to Quit EU’s ‘Frugal Four’
item.description: Denmark will break away from the alliance of frugal nations as it enters the next round of European Union budget negotiations, the Nordic country’s prime minister said, signaling a shift in priorities as security concerns dominate the bloc’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Sanne Wass

media:content.media:description: Mette Frederiksen, right, and the President of the European Parliament Roberta Metsola on June 3.

item.title: Trump Trade ‘Uncertainty Means Inaction’ in Dublin’s Office Market
item.description: Companies spooked by US President Donald Trump’s tariffs are flying blind in many corners of the globe. The uncertainty has even reached the hunt for office space in Dublin, one of Europe’s biggest multinational hubs.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at the missing White House economic forecasts. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.

item.title: South Korea Votes for New Leader to Heal Nation, Spur Growth
item.description: South Koreans headed to the polls Tuesday to elect a new president after an attempt to impose martial law at the end of last year triggered its worst constitutional crisis in decades.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: A voter casts their ballot at a polling station in Incheon, South Korea. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Cuts to US Aid Imperil the World’s Largest HIV Treatment Program
item.description: In South Africa, clinics serving marginalized groups—migrants, gay men and sex workers—are shutting down as funds dry up.
item.dc:creator: Janice Kew, Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Patients begin lining up outside the Witkoppen Clinic in Johannesburg before dawn.
